articles.title: GMC revises physician associate regulation plans after negative consultation findings

articles.description: The NHS is 'busier than ever before' heading into winter and could face an emerging 'quad-demic' as numbers of patients hospitalised with flu, norovirus, COVID-19 and RSV surge, the health service's medical director has warned.
articles.title: NHS 'quad-demic' fears as flu and norovirus cases surge

articles.description: GP leaders have urged caution over the rollout of obesity drug tirzepatide after final draft guidance from NICE set out plans to offer it to almost quarter of a million people over the next three years.
articles.title: Warning over impact on GPs as NICE announces three-year tirzepatide rollout

articles.description: A GP partner served with contract termination notices after refusing to co-operate with a PCN has won a legal appeal with significant implications for general practice.
articles.title: Court victory for GP who refused to join PCN opens new legal window for practices

articles.description: Over the past two years, the number of patients registered with GP practices across England has risen roughly twice as fast as the fully-qualified GP workforce - leaving general practice stretched thinner and thinner. But some areas have bucked the trend - and one area in particular has moved the dial in a remarkable way.
articles.title: How part of England bucked the national trend and grew its GP workforce

articles.description: GP leaders have called for the CQC to pause routine inspections and scrap one-word ratings in recommendations sent to the government.
articles.title: CQC should pause routine inspections and scrap one-word ratings, says RCGP

articles.description: More than half of GPs think existing physician associate (PA) roles in general practice should be phased out, according to a GPonline poll.
articles.title: Most GPs believe PA roles in general practice should be phased out

articles.description: GMC regulation of physician associates (PAs) will begin from next week - and critics of the plans should recognise 'that ship has sailed', the regulator's chief executive has said.
articles.title: No turning back on GMC regulation of physician associates, says chief executive

articles.description: Newly-qualified GPs are still struggling to find work and considering careers abroad despite plans to create more than 1,000 jobs through the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS), GP trainers have warned.
articles.title: ARRS jobs have not solved employment crisis for newly-qualified GPs, trainers warn

articles.description: The RCGP has said it will consult members on what its position should be on legalising assisted dying, as it insisted any change in the law must ensure there are clear protections to allow GPs to opt out of the process.
articles.title: RCGP to consult members over its stance on assisted dying

articles.description: The RCGP has said it will consult members on what its position should be on legalising assisted dying, as it insisted any change in the law must ensure there are clear protections to allow GPs to opt out of the process.
articles.title: RCGP to consult members on its assisted dying position

articles.description: The shortage of GP jobs has driven down locum rates by around 2% in the past six months and pushed more doctors into private sector roles, a sessional GP organisation has warned.
articles.title: GP job shortage forces locums to cut fees and take on private work

articles.description: The Scottish government has promised an extra £13.6m to boost GP recruitment in the current financial year - and warned it was 'completely unacceptable' for practices to bear the brunt of higher employer national insurance costs from April.
articles.title: Scottish government promises £13.6m to boost GP recruitment

articles.description: MPs have backed a bill that would give some terminally adults in England and Wales the right to end their lives.
articles.title: MPs vote through assisted dying bill

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses what happened at last week's England LMCs conference and whether the profession looks set to take more significant industrial action, and the latest update to our GP Insight Workforce Tracker.
articles.title: Podcast: Will GPs step up collective action? Plus the growing gap in underdoctored areas

articles.description: Two thirds of GPs in Scotland are ready to cause 'significant disruption' to services through industrial action, BMA polling reveals.
articles.title: Two thirds of Scottish GPs ready to disrupt services through industrial action

articles.description: General practice delivered a record 38.6m appointments in October this year - or more than 40m including COVID-19 jabs - in the highest ever one-month total recorded.
articles.title: GP appointments hit new record high in October

articles.description: The gap between England's most and least underdoctored areas is growing - with GPs in parts of the country now responsible for more than 1,000 extra patients each than their counterparts in other areas, data from GPonline's GP Insight project reveal.
articles.title: Where in England are patients per GP rising fastest?

articles.description: GPs who graduated outside the UK will make up a growing proportion of the NHS general practice workforce in the coming years, the GMC has said, with the proportion of non-UK graduates in GP training double the national average across other specialties.
articles.title: General practice increasingly reliant on non-UK graduate doctors, says GMC

articles.description: Soaring NHS clinical negligence costs now consume nearly half the amount spent per year on core GP services in England, official figures suggest - as medico-legal experts called for urgent reform.
articles.title: NHS clinical negligence costs nearly half total spend on core GP services

articles.description: Healthcare professionals should always prescribe maintenance or combination treatments, rather than the familiar blue ‘reliever-only’ inhaler, when asthma is first diagnosed, the final guidance from NICE/BTS/SIGN has said.
articles.title: Always prescribe combination treatments for newly diagnosed asthma, final joint guidance says

articles.description: Some practices are considering switching permanent salaried GPs for locums to limit the impact of increased employer national insurance costs from April - along with other radical steps such as quitting the NHS pension scheme, a specialist accountant has warned.
articles.title: Practices could be forced to switch salaried GPs for locums to avoid NI costs

articles.description: The scale of medicines shortages in the UK is putting unprecedented pressure on frontline healthcare professionals including GPs, according to a report that calls for a new national strategy to manage the problem.
articles.title: Medicines shortages are piling unprecedented pressure on frontline NHS staff

articles.description: Nine in 10 GP partners have not received the 6% pay increase promised by the government this year - and two thirds have not seen any pay increase at all, a GPonline survey reveals.
articles.title: GP contract failed to deliver pay rise for two thirds of partners

articles.description: General practice is 'no longer sustainable' and faces 'potential collapse' because of huge cost increases following the autumn budget, LMC leaders have warned - as they backed calls for a special conference amid fears of practice closures and widespread redundancies.
articles.title: Budget threatens 'collapse' of general practice as LMCs back special conference

articles.description: The CQC’s inspection regime is ‘fundamentally flawed’ and the regulator should be scrapped, GPs have said.
articles.title: ‘Fundamentally flawed’ CQC inspection regime should be scrapped, say GPs

articles.description: GPs look set to be balloted on taking ‘more significant industrial action’ following a vote at the England LMCs conference.
articles.title: GPs back call to ballot profession on 'more significant' industrial action

articles.description: Doctors' leaders branded the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) a 'tool of mass general practice destruction' - as LMCs voted to condemn the GP jobs crisis and demand £1.4bn in ARRS cash is moved into core practice funding.
articles.title: ARRS branded a ‘tool of mass general practice destruction’ as LMCs hit out over jobs crisis

articles.description: BMA England GP committee chair Dr Katie Bramall-Stainer has urged GPs to 'keep the faith' and press ahead with collective action in a keynote LMCs conference speech in which she warned the government that cost pressures from the budget must be resourced in full.
articles.title: GPs can break 'toxic' cycle of underfunding through collective action, says GP chair

articles.description: Wes Streeting has told the BMA he 'understands the potential implications' of the budget for GPs and is 'working rapidly' to finalise 2025/26 funding - but a letter to the profession's leaders falls short of guaranteeing that extra costs will be covered.
articles.title: Government 'working fast' to finalise GP funding for 2025/26, says Streeting

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to Dr Gaurav Gupta, the BMA England GP committee lead for premises about why the government needs to invest in the primary care estate if it is serious about growing the workforce and delivering on its plans for a neighbourhood NHS.
articles.title: Podcast: What does the future hold for GP premises?

articles.description: A charity that supports GPs facing financial hardship has helped 15% more people in the first 10 months of 2024 than in the whole of last year, as many qualified GPs continue to struggle to find work.
articles.title: Sharp rise in GPs needing financial help amid jobs crisis, charity warns

articles.description: Debate over physician associate (PA) roles in general practice has intensified this year, with legal battles, calls for strict supervision and limits on their work and the launch of a major government review. In recent months, PA numbers have dropped for the first time - so are they starting to be phased out?
articles.title: Is general practice already starting to phase out physician associates?

articles.description: The national shingles vaccination programme should be expanded to include patients aged 80 and over and all severely immunosuppressed adults aged 18 and over, new Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) guidance recommends.
articles.title: Shingles programme should expand to over-80s, says JCVI

articles.description: The government has commissioned an independent review into physician associate (PA) and anaesthesia associate (AA) roles in the NHS amid widespread safety concerns - sparking calls from the BMA for immediate steps to protect patients.
articles.title: Government launches independent review into safety of physician associate roles

articles.description: The BMA has accused the GMC of seeking to hide its views on physician associates roles and risking erosion of 'what little trust remains' between doctors and their regulator.
articles.title: BMA accuses GMC of 'seeking to conceal' stance on physician associates

articles.description: Dozens of patients have sent messages of condolence after a coroner confirmed that an 'exceptional' Shropshire GP took her own life earlier this year.
articles.title: 'Exceptional' GP took her own life after work pressure

articles.description: The BMA has defended the GP partnership model - arguing it remains viable but has been broken by long-term underfunding - after NHS England’s clinical lead for emergency medicine called for primary care to become a fully salaried service.
articles.title: BMA hits back over NHS official's call to scrap GP partnerships

articles.description: GP practices are absorbing additional risk and workload caring for many thousands of women who face 'devastating' long waits for gynaecology treatment, as their conditions deteriorate and become more complex, a report has warned.
articles.title: 'Devastating' gynaecology waits harming women and driving up GP workload

articles.description: The vast majority of GP practices will be forced to cut staff and patient services and more than one in 10 could be forced to close unless the government covers the increase in employer national insurance payments from next year, a GPonline poll suggests.
articles.title: National insurance hike could force 600 GP practices to close

articles.description: General practice could need a new contract with a revamped funding formula to tackle the fallout from the autumn budget, the BMA England GP committee chair has warned.
articles.title: GPs may need new contract to solve budget fallout, BMA GP leader warns

articles.description: NHS England has backed the GP partnership model after its clinical lead for emergency medicine called for it to be scrapped.
articles.title: Emergency care chief's call to scrap GP partnerships 'not the view of NHS England'

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses how the increase in employer national insurance contributions will affect GP practices, salaried GP pay and some good news about patient satisfaction with general practice.
articles.title: Podcast: Fallout from the budget, how the job shortage has hit GP pay

articles.description: GPs in Northern Ireland will be denied the 6% pay uplift awarded to doctors across the UK for 2024/25 after the government said it was unaffordable - sparking 'anger and outrage' on an scale doctors' leaders say is unprecedented.
articles.title: 'Anger and outrage' as Northern Ireland GPs denied DDRB uplift

articles.description: Wes Streeting has ruled out an exemption to protect GP practices from cost increases announced in the autumn budget and said they are 'not formally part of the NHS', as the BMA warned general practice faces an 'existential threat' without additional support.
articles.title: Streeting says GP practices 'not formally part of the NHS' and rules out tax exemption

articles.description: Routine vaccination against COVID-19 could end for patients aged between 65 and 74 from next autumn under updated advice from the joint committee on vaccination and immunisation (JCVI) - which also repeats its stance that the jabs should no longer be offered to NHS staff.
articles.title: JCVI backs reduced COVID-19 jab programme

articles.description: ICBs will be stripped of their role performance managing hospitals so they can focus on 'building up community and primary care services' to develop a neighbourhood NHS, the health and social care secretary has said.
articles.title: ICBs must focus on 'building up' primary care services, says Streeting

articles.description: The government should create clear targets to define the proportion of eligible people who should receive an NHS health check each year - and consider adding the checks to the QOF, a National Audit Office (NAO) report says.
articles.title: Build NHS health checks into QOF, NAO report suggests

articles.description: GPs will hit out over underfunding of general practice at the Northern Ireland LMCs conference this month - demanding that GMS contract funding should rise to more than the price of annual insurance for a pet hamster.
articles.title: GP funding per patient less than annual hamster insurance, LMCs warn

articles.description: GPs should refer all patients with suspected endometriosis for a transvaginal ultrasound, even if their pelvic or abdominal examination is normal, according to new NICE guidance.
articles.title: Final NICE guidance recommends ultrasound for all patients with suspected endometriosis

articles.description: GPs have been urged to step up collective action after an LMC analysis found the government's autumn budget will drive up costs by £47,000 a year for an average practice - wiping out almost half of the GP contract uplift for 2024/25.
articles.title: Budget threatens to wipe out half of 2024/25 GP contract uplift

articles.description: Patients' overall experience of their GP practice and ease of contacting their practice have improved markedly since the summer, Office for National Statistics (ONS) data show.
articles.title: Patient satisfaction with general practice rising rapidly, ONS data suggest

articles.description: Tens of thousands of people a year could be offered a new version of the anti-smoking medication varenicline - three years after the original drug was withdrawn over safety concerns - after a relaunched generic pill was approved by the Medicines and Healthcare Products Agency (MHRA).
articles.title: NHS to offer new version of anti-smoking pill varenicline to thousands of patients

articles.description: Government plans to hike employer national insurance contributions from April 2025 could cost GP practices the equivalent of 2m appointments a year, analysis by the Liberal Democrats shows.
articles.title: National insurance hike could cost 2m GP appointments, analysis finds

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) has granted prequalification to the molecular diagnostic test for tuberculosis (TB) called Xpert® MTB/RIF Ultra. It is the first test for TB diagnosis and antibiotic susceptibility testing that meets WHO's prequalification standards. 
Tuberculosis is one of the world’s leading infectious disease killers, causing over a million deaths annually and imposing immense socioeconomic burdens, especially in low- and middle-income countries. Accurate and early detection of TB, especially drug-resistant strains, remains a critical and challenging global health priority. 
“This first prequalification of a diagnostic test for tuberculosis marks a critical milestone in WHO’s efforts to support countries in scaling up and accelerating access to high-quality TB assays …
articles.title: WHO announces first prequalification of a tuberculosis diagnostic test

articles.description:
The Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO) is hereby transmitting the report of the second meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) (IHR) Emergency Committee (Committee) regarding the upsurge of mpox 2024, held on Friday 22 November 2024, from 12:00 to 17:00 CET.
Notwithstanding some progress towards controlling the spread of mpox resulting from national and international response efforts, the Committee noted the rising number and continuing geographic spread of mpox cases, especially those due to monkeypox virus clade Ib infection; the operational challenges in the field in need of stronger national commitments; as well as the need to mount and sustain a cohesive response across countries and partners. The Committee advised that the event continues to meet t…
articles.title: Second meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the upsurge of mpox 2024

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) and partners announced 10 projects that will receive almost US$ 2 million in grants to improve capacities in pathogen genomic surveillance. 

The catalytic grant fund was established by the International Pathogen Surveillance Network (IPSN) to support partners from low- and middle-income countries to build their capacities in pathogen genomic analysis. This technology analyses the genetic code of viruses, bacteria and other disease-causing organisms to understand, in conjunction with other data, how easily they spread, and how sick they can make people. This data allows scientists and public health teams to track and respond to infectious disease threats, supports the development of vaccines and treatments and empowers countries to take faster decisions.…
articles.title: International Pathogen Surveillance Network announces first recipients of grants to better understand disease threats

articles.description:
Delegations from over 110 countries are coming together to produce national roadmaps and negotiate a joint declaration on oral health at the first-ever global oral health meeting organized by the World Health Organization (WHO). The declaration is expected to outline collective commitments from Member States to accelerate the implementation of the Global strategy and action plan on oral health 2023–2030.
Oral diseases are the most common noncommunicable diseases (NCDs) worldwide, affecting an estimated 3.5 billion people. Oral health is often misunderstood as just dental health, overlooking its broader importance. Oral diseases include dental caries or cavities, gum disease, tooth loss, oral cancer, noma and birth defects, affecting the mouth, teeth and facial structures that are essential…
articles.title: The first-ever global oral health conference highlights universal health coverage by 2030

articles.description:
Since 7 October 2023, 47% of attacks on health care – 65 out of 137 – have proven fatal to at least one health worker or patient in Lebanon, as of 21 November 2024.

This is a higher percentage than in any active conflict today across the globe – with nearly half of all attacks on health causing the death of a health worker.

In comparison, the global average is 13.3%, based on the SSA’s figures from 13 countries or territories that reported attacks in the same period, 7 October 2023 – 18 November 2024 - among them Ukraine, Sudan and the occupied Palestinian territory (oPt). In the case of oPt, 9.6% of the total number of incidents has resulted in the death of at least one medical professional or patient.

According to SSA, 226 health workers and patients were killed in Lebanon and 199 inj…
articles.title: Lebanon: a conflict particularly destructive to health care

articles.description:
The first-ever Investment Round of the World Health Organization (WHO) reached a culminating moment during the G20 Leaders' Summit today in Rio de Janeiro, chaired by the President of Brazil, H.E. Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Heads of state and government at the G20 voiced strong support for a sustainably funded WHO, additional financial pledges were announced, and incoming G20 Chair South Africa pledged to maintain a focus in 2025 on sustainably financing the Organization. 
The support was reflected in the G20 Rio de Janeiro Leaders’ Declaration which said: “We reiterate the central coordinating role of the World Health Organization (WHO) in the global health architecture, supported by adequate, predictable, transparent, flexible and sustainable financing. We support the conducting of the W…
articles.title: WHO Investment Round: culminating moment at G20 Summit as leaders pledge

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) has granted Emergency Use Listing (EUL) for the LC16m8 mpox vaccine, making it the second mpox vaccine to be supported by WHO following the Director-General’s declaration of an mpox public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC) on 14 August 2024.
This decision is expected to facilitate increased and timely access to vaccines in communities where mpox outbreaks are surging. In 2024, cases have been reported across 80 countries, including 19 countries in Africa, based on data as of 31 October 2024. The Democratic Republic of the Congo, the hardest-hit country, recorded a large majority of suspected cases – over 39 000 – as well as more than 1000 deaths.
Today’s move is particularly relevant as the Government of Japan has announced that it will d…
articles.title: WHO adds LC16m8 mpox vaccine to Emergency Use Listing

articles.description:
As world leaders arrive in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, for the G20 Summit this weekend, the city’s iconic Christ the Redeemer statue will be illuminated in the colour teal. The Brazilian advocates behind this effort are among many around the globe joining the World Health Organization (WHO) to mobilize efforts on a worldwide “Day of Action for Cervical Cancer Elimination.” Other countries are marking the day with campaigns to provide human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination and screening, launching new health policies to align with the world’s first-ever effort to eliminate a cancer, and raising awareness in communities. 
Four years ago to the day, 194 countries resolved to eliminate cervical cancer and WHO launched a global strategy. Since then, significant progress has been made. At least 144 …
articles.title: WHO and partners rally cervical cancer elimination efforts

articles.description:
Worldwide, there were an estimated 10.3 million cases of measles in 2023, a 20% increase from 2022, according to new estimates from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Inadequate immunization coverage globally is driving the surge in cases.
Measles is preventable with two doses of measles vaccine; yet more than 22 million children missed their first dose of measles vaccine in 2023. Globally, an estimated 83% of children received their first dose of measles vaccine last year, while only 74% received the recommended second dose.
Coverage of 95% or greater of two doses of measles vaccine is needed in each country and community to prevent outbreaks and protect populations from one of the world’s most contagious human viruses.
“Meas…
articles.title: Measles cases surge worldwide, infecting 10.3 million people in 2023

articles.description:
The number of adults living with diabetes worldwide has surpassed 800 million, more than quadrupling since 1990, according to new data released in The Lancet on World Diabetes Day. The analysis, conducted by the NCD Risk Factor Collaboration (NCD-RisC) with support from the World Health Organization (WHO), highlights the scale of the diabetes epidemic and an urgent need for stronger global action to address both rising disease rates and widening treatment gaps, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).
“We have seen an alarming rise in diabetes over the past three decades, which reflects the increase in obesity, compounded by the impacts of the marketing of unhealthy food, a lack of physical activity and economic hardship," said WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebre…
articles.title: Urgent action needed as global diabetes cases increase four-fold over past decades
